Film Aesthetics, Fantasy, and the Expression of Adolescent Desire in Le Souffle au coeur (Murmur of the Heart) and Call Me by Your Name

In focusing on the role of fantasy in the sexuation (the subject's adoption of sexual being) of adolescents, the analysis by Turim of Le Souffle au coeur, Murmur of the Heart, Louis Malle, 1971 and Call Me by Your Name, Luca Guadagnino, 2017 develops how the films treat this process in adolescent males. Intertexts of Murmur of the Heart propose variations as regards gender and fantasy, with particular focus on George Bataille's Ma mère and its filmic adaptation by Christophe Honoré, on Anges Varda's Kung Fu Master!, and Bertolucci's Luna. Turim critiques how psychoanalysis has in the past treated sexuation and suggests an updated approach that rectifies outdated and erroneous assumptions about queer sexual development, as well as revising the Oedipus complex. Throughout Turim considers the films’ aesthetics, a gentle embrace of an art cinema style that remains entirely committed to emotive narrative and is therefore softer and more accessible to a larger public than are the more demanding and trenchant experiments with form that other art cinema pursues. Their young male protagonists become the edge that sharpens this softness, for the process of sexuation in adolescence is not mild or easy and remains daringly depicted in both films. These art films speculate on the logic of desire and the force of fantasy, allowing us to think philosophically about the specificities of the complex relationship of situated ethics to fantasy.
